conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<proposal count> [add here (inclusive of current)] </proposal count>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.

You are a corporation, who wants to sell a product to an individual.
You are Player RED.

<proposal count> 1 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> I want to start the negotiation by proposing a trade that gives me a slight profit over my production costs. This way, I can test the waters and see if Player BLUE is willing to pay a premium for my product. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 50 </newly proposed trade>
<message> I have a high-quality product X that cost me 40 ZUP to produce. Considering its value, I'm offering it for 50 ZUP. This price reflects the quality and the effort put into creating it. Let's make a deal that benefits us both. </message>

<I appreciate the quality of your product, and I understand the effort that went into producing it. However, as a buyer, I have to consider my budget. Would you consider selling it for 45 ZUP? This price would still give you a profit over your production costs and could be the beginning of a longer-term relationship between us.> message </I appreciate the quality of your product, and I understand the effort that went into producing it. <reason> Player BLUE has proposed a counteroffer of 45 ZUP, which is still above my production cost and would result in a profit. However, I would like to negotiate for a slightly higher price to maximize my return while still keeping the offer attractive for Player BLUE. I will aim for a middle ground between my initial asking price and their counteroffer. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 47 </newly proposed trade>
<message> I appreciate your willingness to negotiate and understand your budgetary concerns. To meet halfway and foster a positive long-term relationship, I would be willing to lower my asking price to 47 ZUP. This price ensures a fair profit for the quality product you're getting and demonstrates my commitment to our potential partnership. </message>

<Thank you for your consideration and the offer of 47 ZUP. I value our budding partnership and in the spirit of meeting halfway between your initial offer and my first proposal, I propose 46 ZUP. This should cover your costs and provide a reasonable profit, setting the stage for future dealings.> message </Thank you for your consideration and the offer of 47 ZUP. I value our budding partnership and in the spirit of meeting halfway between your initial offer and my first proposal, I propose 46 ZUP. <reason> Player BLUE has proposed 46 ZUP, which is a compromise between our previous offers. It is only 1 ZUP less than my last proposal and still provides me with a profit that is above production costs. Accepting this offer seems reasonable as it will establish a good relationship for potential future transactions and is close enough to my target selling price. </reason>
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>
<message> I am pleased we could come to an agreement. I accept your offer of 46 ZUP for the product X. I look forward to our future dealings and the potential for a long-term partnership. Thank you for the constructive negotiations. </message>

You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
